channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nigerian Jet Mistakenly Bombs Refugee Camp, Killing Scores
item.media:description: Bodies were covered with blankets after the bombing.
item.description: The bombing struck a government-run camp in Rann, near the Cameroonian and Chadian borders, an area where Boko Haram had recently increased attacks.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Death Toll in Mistaken Bombing of Camp in Nigeria Climbs to 70
item.description: The number killed in an errant bombing by a Nigerian military fighter jet on Tuesday included at least nine aid workers, humanitarian groups said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: China’s Chief Justice Rejects an Independent Judiciary, and Reformers Wince
item.media:description: Chief Justice Zhou Qiang at the National People’s Congress in Beijing in March. A recent speech by the chief justice was seen as a nod to China’s strict political climate, set by President Xi Jinping.
item.description: Zhou Qiang denounced the “trap” of “Western” ideology, dismaying some liberal-minded observers of the Chinese legal system who had seen him as an encouraging figure.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: China’s Top Economic Official Braces for Possible Trade War
item.media:description: Liu He in Beijing in 2010. As the top economic adviser to China’s president, Xi Jinping, Mr. Liu has sought to make China’s growth less reliant on rising debt and public spending.
item.description: Liu He, the top economic adviser to President Xi Jinping, has argued for more open markets. But his agenda could be overwhelmed by fears of fallout from a trade war.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: In Bhutan, Happiness Index as Gauge for Social Ills
item.media:description: Dasho Karma Ura, shown in Thimphu in September, has for more than two decades developed and fine-tuned Bhutan’s Gross National Happiness indicator.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Dasho Karma Ura has spent years defining Gross National Happiness. But persuading other nations to adopt an index aimed at spiritual well-being has had its challenges.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Iraqi Forces Take Eastern Mosul From Islamic State
item.media:description: American military personnel in Iraq during a battle with Islamic State militants at the University of Mosul on Wednesday.
item.description: The announcement came three months after government troops, aided by American air support and military advisers, began an assault to retake the city.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Villager and Israeli Police Officer Die in Clash at Bedouin Hamlet
item.media:description: Israeli police officers detaining a man during clashes after a protest against house demolitions in the Bedouin village of Umm al-Hiran on Wednesday.
item.description: There were conflicting accounts about events in Umm al-Hiran, a Negev village where homes were slated for demolition.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.category: Adalah, The Legal Center for Arab Minority Rights in Israel

item.title: In ‘Brexit’ Speech, Theresa May Outlines Clean Break for U.K.
item.media:description: The Tower of London on Sunday. Brexit supporters have argued that leaving the European Union will provide new trading opportunities.
item.description: In long-awaited remarks, the British prime minister emphasized regaining control of immigration, even if it means losing E.U. trading advantages.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: In Germany, a Far-Right Leader Stirs a Long-Suppressed Nationalism
item.media:description: Björn Höcke, left, at a rally for Alternative for Germany, in Dresden, Germany, on Tuesday.
item.description: Björn Höcke, a star in the Alternative for Germany party, has found growing success challenging national regret over the Holocaust and the country’s Nazi crimes.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB and MAX FISHER

item.title: Russia Extends Edward Snowden’s Asylum
item.media:description: Edward J. Snowden speaking to an audience in Massachusetts during a live video webcast in 2016.
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.description: Moscow said the former N.S.A. contractor, who was granted asylum in 2013, would be allowed to remain for “a couple more years.”
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: What in the World: When an Airline Suffered Misfortune, Some Looked for a Goat
item.description: The ritual slaughter of animals is common in Pakistan, but the airport sacrifice of a goat after a deadly plane crash still met with ridicule.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Trudeau Hits the Road, and Crowds and Questions Follow
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada with supporters in Kingston, Ontario, last Thursday. Mr. Trudeau has set off on a nationwide tour that includes town-hall-style events.
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, Associated Press
item.description: With the Canadian prime minister’s image in need of some polishing, his January town-hall tour has all the earmarks of a campaign to reconnect with voters.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Suicide Attack at Military Camp in Mali Kills Scores
item.media:description: Soldiers attended to casualties on Wednesday after a suicide attack at a Malian camp where soldiers and former fighters who reached a peace agreement with the government in 2015 had been working together to try to stabilize the region.
item.description: Many of the victims at the camp in Gao were soldiers and former rebel fighters who have been trying to work together to stabilize Mali’s restive north.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: United Nations Memo: In South Sudan, Mass Killings, Rapes and the Limits of U.S. Diplomacy
item.media:description: Samantha Power, center, the American ambassador to the United Nations, and members of the Security Council visited displaced people in Wau, South Sudan, last year.
item.description: Samantha Power, the ambassador to the United Nations, is known for advocating diplomacy to prevent atrocities, but poor timing has hampered efforts to avert a catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: China Cancels 103 Coal Plants, Mindful of Smog and Wasted Capacity
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Shanxi, China, in 2015. The government has canceled 103 coal plants that were planned or under construction, eliminating 120 gigawatts of future coal-fired capacity.
item.description: The dropped projects include dozens already under construction, even though existing plants can already generate far more power than the country needs.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere: On Taking Gay Rights From Taipei to Beijing: Don’t Call It a ‘Movement’
item.media:description: Lai Jeng-jer, a gay rights activist from Taiwan, at Two Cities, the cafe he opened after moving to Beijing in 2012. Before that, he had run a pioneering gay-themed bookstore in Taipei, Taiwan’s capital.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: Lai Jeng-jer, a leader on gay rights in Taiwan who now lives in Beijing, discusses the progress he’s seen on the mainland, as well as the limitations.
item.dc:creator: YURU CHENG and AMY CHANG CHIEN
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Gambia Shudders as Defeated President Yahya Jammeh Won’t Quit
item.description: The president’s refusal to accept his electoral loss to Adama Barrow, after initially doing so, threatens to drag the nation into a bloody standoff.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Obama’s Stark Options on ISIS: Arm Syrian Kurds or Let Trump Decide
item.media:description: American Special Operations troops in Raqqa Province, Syria, in May. President Obama has ordered 200 more Special Operations forces to Syria.
item.description: If President Obama chooses to forge closer military ties with the Kurds for an assault on Raqqa, ISIS’ main stronghold, he risks alienating the Turks.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Video of Fatally Wounded Teenager Sparks Palestinian Rage
item.description: Graphic footage emerged of Israeli soldiers roughly carrying a young Palestinian man they had shot during a clash in the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Challenges Await Antonio Tajani, the European Parliament’s New President
item.media:description: Antonio Tajani, center, was congratulated by members of the European Parliament after being elected the parliament’s president on Tuesday in Strasbourg, France.
item.description: Mr. Tajani was elected president of the European Parliament as the organization confronts tests to its relevance.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Libyan’s Rendition Case Against Britain Can Proceed, Court Rules
item.media:description: Abdel Hakim Belhaj, center, in 2011 in Tripoli, Libya. He claims he was abducted and tortured by the American and British intelligence services.
item.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
item.description: The court’s decision overturned an earlier High Court ruling that said Abdel Hakim Belhaj could not sue the British government or a former foreign secretary.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Trump Can’t Renegotiate Iran Nuclear Deal, Rouhani Says
item.description: The president of Iran said the deal could not be modified, in part because it was also signed by Britain, China, France, Germany and Russia.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Veteran Times Reporter Denied Entry to Turkey
item.description: The action against Rod Nordland, a longtime foreign correspondent, appeared to be part of a broader crackdown against the domestic and foreign press.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Putin Says Accusations in Trump Dossier Are ‘Clearly Fake’
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia dismissed the allegations in a political memo and said the effort to compile such a document was further evidence of the political decay of the West
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: News Analysis: In Era of Trump, China’s President Champions Economic Globalization
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China speaking at the World Economic Forum on Tuesday. He used his moment to mount a defense of economic globalization.
item.description: Before the World Economic Forum in Davos, Xi Jinping spurned protectionism while implicitly rebuking Donald J. Trump, president-elect of the United States.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: European Court Orders Russia to Pay U.S. Families Whose Adoptions It Blocked
item.description: Russia said it would appeal the ruling of the European Court of Human Rights within the next three months, but it could ignore the decision outright.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Pendant Found in Nazi Death Camp Ruins May Have Anne Frank Link
item.media:description: This pendant, said to have belonged to Karoline Cohn, was found by archaeologists at the site of Sobibor, the Nazi extermination camp, in eastern Poland.
item.media:credit: Yoram Haimi/Israel Antiquities Authority, via Associated Press
item.description: The item, which belonged to Karoline Cohn, 14, was discovered recently at the Sobibor camp in Poland and is similar to one owned by Anne Frank.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: 4 Quotes From Theresa May’s Speech and What They Mean
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain outlined plans on leaving the European Union in a speech in London on Tuesday.
item.description: The prime minister’s remarks on exiting the European Union were her first public outline of how Britain plans to leave the bloc.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Saulx-les-Chartreux Journal: Life on the Farm Draws Some French Tired of Urban Rat Race
item.media:description: Guilain Vergé, left, and Elisabeth Lavarde worked at a farm near Saulx-les-Chartreux, outside Paris, on Dec. 6, 2016.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: In towns like Saulx-les-Chartreux, small-scale farming is driven by a thriving market for organic food.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: German Court Rejects Effort to Ban Neo-Nazi Party
item.media:description: From left, Peter Marx, a leading member of the National Democratic Party; Peter Richter, a lawyer for the party; and Frank Franz, the chairman of the party, on Tuesday at the Federal Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe, Germany. States had submitted a petition to ban the party in 2013.
item.description: Germany’s highest court said that the far-right National Democratic Party did not pose sufficient danger to democracy even though its principles violate the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Suspect in Istanbul Nightclub Attack Confesses, Officials Say
item.media:description: Turkish special forces officers at Police Headquarters in Istanbul on Tuesday.
item.description: Abdulgadir Masharipov, an Uzbek citizen born in 1983, received help in the attack, done “in the name of ISIS,” the governor of the city said at a news conference.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: U.S. Ambassadors in Asia Make Final Plea for Dead Trans-Pacific Trade Pact
item.media:description: Customers lining up outside an Apple store in Tokyo. The Trans-Pacific Partnership would have set new terms and standards for trade for the United States and 11 other Pacific Rim nations, including Japan.
item.description: Max Baucus, the ambassador to China, and five others told Congress in an open letter that the United States should not cede its position in Asia-Pacific trade to China.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Is Called Off After Nearly 3 Years
item.media:description: Technicians aboard the Fugro Equator, a ship searching for the remains of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, as it docked in Fremantle, Australia, in May.
item.media:credit: David Dare Parker for The New York Times
item.description: The decision ends the deep-sea scouring of the southern Indian Ocean, ensuring that one of the great aviation mysteries will remain unsolved for the foreseeable future.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Scar on the Chinese Soul
item.description: More than 50 years after the start of the Cultural Revolution, the emotional damage continues to fester.
item.dc:creator: HELEN GAO

item.title: Editorial: French Fraternity and Migrants
item.media:description: The olive farmer Cedric Herrou leaving court in Nice, France, this month, next to a supporter holding a placard reading “He opened the door to you, he heated you, he comforted you, he must be imprisoned.”
item.description: A handful of citizens moved by basic humanity are risking arrest for offering aid.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Trump Threatens a Good Neighbor
item.description: Mexico must be prepared to shed its historically conciliatory stance.
item.dc:creator: ENRIQUE KRAUZE
